content: The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" establishes a standard of proof for service-connection of mental health conditions related to military sexual trauma. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" amends Section 1154 of title 38, United States Code, to establish a standard of proof for veterans claiming a covered mental health condition related to military sexual trauma during active service. The Secretary must accept a diagnosis by a mental health professional, along with evidence of trauma, and resolve doubts in favor of the veteran. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" establishes a standard of proof for veterans claiming a covered mental health condition related to military sexual trauma during active service. The Secretary must accept a diagnosis by a mental health professional and resolve doubts in favor of the veteran. Service-connection may be rebutted by clear and convincing evidence, and reasons for granting or denying service-connection must be recorded in full. In the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed military sexual trauma. The "Ruth Moore Act of 2013" establishes a standard of proof for veterans claiming a covered mental health condition related to military sexual trauma during active service. The Act defines military sexual trauma as psychological trauma resulting from a physical assault, battery, or sexual harassment during active military service. Additionally, the Act requires annual reports on claims for disabilities incurred or aggravated by military sexual trauma. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on covered claims for disabilities related to military sexual trauma, including the number and percentage of claims by sex that were approved or denied. The annual report to Congress on covered claims for disabilities related to military sexual trauma includes the number and percentage of approved and denied claims by sex, common reasons for denials, pending claims, and the average processing time for claims.
